qas.question: When was the first major controversy that surfaced from the book?
What event in the novel was heavily criticized for being a plot device?
In letters to local newspapers, what subplot in the book received the most complaints?

answers.text: Mayella Ewell's attraction to Tom Robinson

qas.question: According to the National Education Association, what was the only book to receive more complaints in 1968?

context: One of the first incidents of the book being challenged was in Hanover, Virginia, in <a0_0>1966<a0_0/>: a parent protested that the use of <a1_0>rape<a1_0/> as a plot device was immoral. Johnson cites examples of letters to local newspapers, which ranged from amusement to fury; those letters expressing the most outrage, however, complained about <a2_0>Mayella Ewell's attraction to Tom Robinson<a2_0/> over the depictions of rape. Upon learning the school administrators were holding hearings to decide the book's appropriateness for the classroom, Harper Lee sent $10 to The Richmond News Leader suggesting it to be used toward the enrollment of "the Hanover County School Board in any first grade of its choice". The National Education Association in 1968 placed the novel second on a list of books receiving the most complaints from private organizations—after <a3_0>Little Black Sambo<a3_0/>.
